repnme.cdata!:
Yemen - Institutional Development for
            Public Administration, Legal and Judicial Devlopment and
            Public Sector Management Adjustment Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The report covers three projects. The
            Institutional Development for Public Administration Project
            (IDPAP) had the following ratings: highly unsatisfactory
            outcome, unlikely sustainability, negligible institutional
            development impact, unsatisfactory Bank performance, and
            highly unsatisfactory Borrower performance. The Legal and
            Judicial Development Project had the following ratings:
            moderately unsatisfactory outcome, unlikely sustainability,
            modest institutional development impact, unsatisfactory Bank
            performance, and satisfactory Borrower performance. The
            Public Sector Management Adjustment Project had the
            following ratings: moderately unsatisfactory outcome,
            unlikely sustainability, modest institutional development
            impact, moderately satisfactory Bank performance, and
            moderately satisfactory Borrower performance. Experience
            with these projects highlights the following lessons: (a)
            when the project environment changes dramatically, the Bank
            must be ready to restructure key projects in the portfolio;
            (b) the Bank must be more prepared to stay the course in
            critical governance sectors; and (c) reforms need to be
            supported with experienced staff based in the Yemen field office.

repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Yemen - Public Sector
            Management Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Sector Management Adjustment
            Credit Project's significant progress was made towards
            achieving the stated objectives and outcomes. The
            project's overall outcome was therefore rated as
            satisfactory. The general lessons learned from this project
            are: Public administration reforms require serious
            government commitment and ownership and are likely to
            succeed if they are homegrown. Reforms that require
            coordination between several agencies require a change in
            work practices and culture. The single-tranche disbursement
            mechanism provides a clear understanding of the prior
            actions that the government needs to undertake. The
            country-specific lessons include: Coordination among
            agencies to achieve a common objective or goal is difficult
            in practice especially in Yemen. In a country with
            relatively low technical capacity, a policy-based adjustment
            credit also needs to be complemented by technical assistance
            that supports all affected agencies. The other lessons
            learned is to set realistic objectives that are clearly
            associated with Credit conditionality. Moreover, major
            changes are needed for the future: a focus on outcomes; a
            focus on poverty reduction objectives in setting expenditure
            priorities; greater attention to incentives, competition,
            and public participation; more access to technical
            assistance in implementation of certain areas; and engaging
            civil society and political leadership in owning and
            pursuing reforms to ensure sustainability overtime.

5084406.majtheme: Public sector governance,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!:
Yemen - Public Sector Management Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Sector Management Adjustment
            Credit Project aims to a) begin to redefine the role of the
            state to focus attention and resources on essential
            functions while developing an incentive framework for civil
            servants to carry out their new mandates; b) strengthen
            budget implementation, monitoring, and control by
            introducing new procedures and systems for monitoring
            expenditures and for increasing the transparency and
            coherency of budgetary procedures; and c) improve the
            efficiency, effectiveness, and poverty focus of public
            expenditures; and d) improve the tax administration system
            to increase transparency and enhance and diversify domestic
            resource mobilization. Potential benefits include improved
            management of Yemen's economy, modernization of human
            resource and financial management practices, support to
            private sector development by starting to reduce cumbersome
            bureaucracy; and improved public services. More appropriate
            allocations of public resources will also benefit the
            population as a whole, and the poor in particular, who
            currently suffer from the lack of coherence in the public
            expenditure program targeted to and delivery of essential
            services such as public health, education, and safety net programs.
